header.title: Linux: Running eclimd in the background.

body.p: For linux systems, eclim ships with scripts with can be installed into your distribution's init.d, or equivalent. This has the added benefit of allow you to run eclimd in the background and optionally start it automatically when your system boots up.
body.note: If your distribution has an alternate means for implementing initd scripts, please let me know. You may also be able to adapt the generic initd script for eclimd to suit your distribution. If so, please submit those changes back so that other users may benefit from your work.

section.title: Gentoo
section.p:
Since gentoo has their own framework for writing initd scripts, eclim ships with dedicated files for deployment on gentoo systems.
To install on gentoo simply follow these steps:

ol.li: Copy the file $ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclim_version/bin/native/gentoo/etc/init.d/eclimd to your system's /etc/init.d directory.
Copy the file $ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclim_version/bin/native/gentoo/etc/conf.d/eclimd to your system's /etc/conf.d directory.
Edit your new /etc/conf.d/eclimd file according to your system. At the very least you will need to change the ECLIM_USER and probably the JAVA_HOME and ECLIPSE_HOME

If you wish to have eclimd start automatically when your system boots, you can then add eclimd to your system's default run level:
$ rc-update add eclimd default

section.title: Other Distributions
section.p: For all other distributions, eclim includes a generic initd script, which can be installed as follows:

ol.li: Copy the file $ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclim_version/bin/native/linux/etc/init.d/eclimd to your system's /etc/init.d directory, or equivalent.
Edit your new /etc/init.d/eclimd file according to your system. At the very least you will need to change the ECLIM_USER and probably the JAVA_HOME and ECLIPSE_HOME

If you wish to have eclimd start automatically when your system boots, you can then add eclimd to your system's default run level. How you accomplish this however, is dependent upon your distribution. Please see your distribution's documentation for more information, but feel free to notify me of that process and I can begin compiling a list here for other users to reference.
